document.title: D101 Standards Upload Go Formative - Standards

4F76BF4CF7EA4F089B5AAE84F7DEC1EB.description: Skills and Techniques: demonstrate appropriate art skills, craftsmanship skills, and knowledge in the creation of artwork.

2105D9AE23424C64965B77671E668A6A.description: Presenting and Responding: analyze/interpret/ evaluate techniques of artwork both personally and professionally

2462DE1450644D64B296C060C54FA02F.description: Creating and Connecting: generate, develop, and refine artistic ideas/work that can relate to personal experiences, society, cultural, or historical context.Â

98BBD74D5DE84EDEA66B46EDA2FD0D66.description: Demonstrates grade level appropriate skills while creating, presenting, and responding to art.

4EB0F327F9884F069610FCA7EB850B33.description: Cooperation, participation and appropriate use of materials.

A69642A2ABBF4E6F9DFEB06E4D5B89D4.description: Connect - Connect music to personal experience, history and culture.

6B28DA1F9E3D45C2A8FD6B63961445F5.description: Respond - Evaluate musical pieces or performances in order to discuss them.

77E9B71D6DE54834A264AF84844481CE.description: Perform - Rehearse musical pieces in order to perform with understanding.

6A36E8EE583D4E66929C08D9DCDFB75E.description: Create - Develop, organize and evaluate personal musical ideas.

4AA80F71E9014369AF95813B34ABC584.description: Demonstrates grade level appropriate skills while creating, performing, or responding to music.

E4DFC250913243DB91BFE7C2740048E4.description: Cooperation, participation and appropriate use of materials.

267E31E90841482CBEAB38C038955FA9.description: Recognizes the value of physical activity for health enjoyment, challenge, self expressions and/or social interactions

7A0CC3A33F18412FA2B070789248689A.description: Demonstrates the knowledge and and skills to achieve and maintain a healthy level of physical activity and fitness

B4138A8F75274BF5B317449B60750C13.description: Applies knowledge of concepts/strategies related to movement and performance

28D5771767E04262BD6E93ABFEBBACAF.description: Demonstrate competency in a variety of motor skills and movement patterns

0D8B8C321A2B4C36B8B5B6362C392B9D.description: Demonstrates grade level appropriate PE skills and knowledge.

77B698CF29E54296AA7DD40D61209367.description: Exhibits responsible personal and social behaviors that respects self and others

CDDD58DDDEC34C6F9C4FC19B360E26EF.description: Cooperation, participation and appropriate use of materials.

274D45A6E6BE4BA5B5CB7466E6EEF77A.description: Summarize the rights and responsibilities of being a United States citizen as stated in the Constitution through a project.

D05BF7C699AB45A09C1B4A6FB8F225F4.description: Examine the Preamble to the Constitution in order to understand the purpose of the Constitution.

8DA965AEDDDC43258A5445D2FD3C12C1.description: Define citizenship and give examples of how to be a good citizen.

FC3898FC1F57418B8C2DA64D55F61C74.description: Define independence and give the political, religious, and economic reasons why America wanted freedom.

E1B9DFB9E6EC4424A285F33A87F9C4BE.description: Design a map that includes landforms and a map key.

9164B5D5986444B394E16FE1239D448F.description: Compare and contrast landforms including mountains, hills, plains, valleys, deserts, rivers and lakes within the United States.

70CF3D5695664E848FF0BBFF1551A04E.description: Identify and locate the seven continents and the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, label a compass rose with the cardinal directions, and identify the location of the United States.

C9F65A57D9E34753A227D9B2A41ED069.description: Create a visual that illustrates and describes the history and development of Western Springs and how it relates to the rest of the state.

3DCF20039A0A4812AA590D6BFC4F5D67.description: Analyze why settlers chose to live in Western Springs and why people today choose to live in Western Springs.

C1C4F97B9FA34E53B7B2A6358AB2641C.description: Sequence the events that led to the development of the Western Springs community.

E55907A8B1C44C61895C51073AB7E8F7.description: Describe the Potawatomi tribe and their influence on the local area.

B69716A062B645848F04C30381394CA4.description: History and Development of Western Springs

D8D3F5ED51A0410D9ED177EEB70EE939.description: Define citizenship and give examples of how to be a good citizen within a community.

EC26170E7FB049FD973FF983B7535A01.description: Create an example community which depicts the characteristics of one of the learned types of communities.

64B39AF471BB4A5EB2D4DBB3622DA931.description: Compare and contrast the three major types of communities (urban, suburban, and rural).

A2744049F6EA4172A55907570A651CAC.description: Describe a place and event that could take place in an urban, suburban, and rural community.

9F08CC06183D4231A07BE80739013644.description: Define an urban, suburban, and rural community.

8F82A94FF551460F9EB3A27C0B9202E8.description: Produce an ecosystem model that incorporates the interdependent relationships between animals and plants.

D57CA930AD3041398E241727C29A69D5.description: Develop a simple model or role play to mimic the function of an animal in dispersing seeds or pollinating plants.

B1020C034F234EABAEB0A0CF4AD45C81.description: Identify examples of predator/prey relationships within each habitat.

F1D144777B6043DE91BB6A995A01760A.description: Compare omnivores, carnivores, and herbivores and provide examples of each.

2740EA470FAD4E05B39DA382F2AE8863.description: Match animals to their habitat. (i.e. diorama)

8FDB168174E44A0E9177D23946C813F9.description: List plants and animals in different habitats (Terrestrial: forests, deserts, grasslands; Aquatic: saltwater and freshwater), using text and media.

69F92B5EBADC404C827117A53A4B1EF5.description: Collect and record data of plant growth, make comparisons in discussion based on variables tested, and draw conclusions (light vs. darkness, water vs. no water).

8DF87CCC5C644F6CB25C4307EEB772D0.description: Collaboratively plan an investigation to determine the cause and effect relationship between plants and sunlight and plants and water.

B3F926D9462C4C47A23A17A7D37C0DF8.description: Match the parts of the Scientific Method (question, hypothesis, experiment, observations, conclusions) with their definition. (see graphic organizer and âI Am a Scientistâ lesson)

EF92C3F7D4F546C898EE453761956818.description: Record which of a given set of materials have altered properties after being heated or cooled and if this change can be reversed (i.e. water, crayons, shrinky dinks, wood).

5A250DFEAF9149A89A2F39C5B5DB2D23.description: Build two different structures using the same materials to show how an object can be disassembled and made into a new object(s). [Teaching connections: properties of materials determine usefulness within a structure, and changes can be reversed.]

FDEB4C0A3FB74FC69EFD1A474A8B559A.description: Analyze data obtained from testing different materials (plastic tubing, nail, cardboard, wire, wooden block, felt) to determine which materials are best suited for an intended purpose.

7D3C1CBF505A473ABFFA987CAF34C9F6.description: Describe and classify materials by their observable properties (strength, flexibility, hardness, texture, color, absorbency).

78D581A9C5A643798772632383D3AB08.description: Record a list of solutions designed to slow or prevent wind or water from changing the shape of the land as a group.

1B50747F08754A2B81FB9B83C0D61D4D.description: Create a model that represents one of the processes that shapes or alters the shape of the land. (i.e. technology project, cookie experiment)

F21C342566DA449F9237177CC16500E2.description: Produce an evidence-based report of a recent earth event shaping or altering the earth using media.

8ED3EBD4BB2244D6A3524E02B422D3C0.description: Describe earth events (i.e. earthquakes, tornadoes, volcanic eruptions, tsunamis, hurricanes, floods, erosion) and classify them as occurring quickly or slowly.

5D84F25F0D6B440D970F81F8359C0106.description: Develop and present a model to represent the shapes and kinds of land and bodies of water in an area.

7D140CE05E074396A065BF39286E68A2.description: Identify where water is found and the types of bodies of water (i.e. oceans, lakes, rivers, streams).

5F13A806365D470180910C1EA8AEDD7E.description: Determine the meaning of words and phrases in a text.

8930A19E9EF04DDC9FFDE159246F0CDC.description: Describe how words and phrases (e.g., regular beats, alliteration, rhymes, repeated lines) supply rhythm and meaning in a story, poem, or song.

B63244AE2A974418AEA8E4C27449D543.description: Use words and phrases acquired through conversations, reading and being read to, and responding to texts, including using adjectives and adverbs to describe (e.g., When other kids are happy that makes me happy.)

FE7C99B202D74BA59C2DA9844BC145E3.description: Consult glossaries, dictionaries, and other print and digital tools (e.g., Oxford English Dictionary Online, Etymology Online, Latin Dictionary), to determine or clarify the meanings of words and phrases.

9D3FB136EAD74DC3AD1D1AD446601BC9.description: Distinguish shades of meaning among closely related verbs (e.g., toss, throw, hurl) and closely related adjectives (e.g., thin, slender, skinny, scrawny).

113C7ADCED0349C59B19F582811C19E2.description: Apply knowledge of the meaning of individual words to determine the meaning of compound words (e.g., lighthouse/birdhouse, bookshelf/bookmark).

285084E3781545F4B06F0DE1927FCD01.description: Utilize a known base word as a clue to the meaning of an unknown word with the same base.

A4B8AF77D68A4F149D99E39037A0D5D0.description: Determine the meaning of the new word formed when a known affix is added to a known base. (e.g., happy/unhappy, tell/retell)

425F5B3C473547ADA12DDBF54A59170A.description: Use sentence-level context as a clue to the meaning of an unknown or multiple meaning word/phrase. (e.g., light).

7FA0F0DD065C4540A3D706F1A4804267.description: Â Identify and explore words with common phoneme-grapheme correspondences that have alternate pronunciations (e.g. most/cost, bear/near).

1B4D6E762B224791B17DFC8FBB7AEA1B.description: Read words with common prefixes and suffixes.

BE305CE26CB34EFCBC4884758492A79E.description: Read decodable two-syllable words with short and long vowels (digraphs).

467139E1F3FB4CE59547FEA702258ADA.description: Â Use spelling-sound (phoneme-grapheme) correspondences (e.g., long and short vowels, vowel/consonant digraphs, trigraphs, consonant clusters/blends, vowel r, and base/affixes)Â

1AF077C2F7BE4A9787F090E836B8E41B.description: Distinguish long and short single-letter vowel phonemes when reading decodable one-syllable words (e.g. bake, spot, mat).

FB6BA04B206E47A295F8FA66FA9FC4CB.description: Produce complete sentences when appropriate to task and situation in order to provide requested detail or clarification.

6879E6D5379A4C13B8CD679D8C438505.description: Create audio recordings of stories or poems; add drawings or other visual displays to stories or recounts of experiences when appropriate to clarify ideas, thoughts, and feelings.

24974D009BEB4C5BB612FA454EFDA9F2.description: Tell a story or recount an experience with appropriate facts and relevant, descriptive details, speaking audibly in coherent sentences.

884B9C5D60A844E2B4A42F61C1F8F026.description: Ask and answer questions about what a speaker says in order to clarify comprehension, gather additional information, or deepen understanding of a topic or issue.

86CC185465014D40846AC53A41E23389.description: Recount or describe key ideas or details from a text read aloud or information presented orally or through other media.

BC03D1934A934ECE9DE855E2209622C9.description: Ask for clarification and further explanation as needed about the topics and texts under discussion.

A12D36EAECEF47409122101504DBC81D.description: Build on othersâ talk in conversations by linking comments to the remarks of others.

15F6DB1E759A4739877AB268AD0EBF8C.description: Follow agreed-upon rules for discussions (e.g., gaining the floor in respectful ways, listening to others with care, speaking one at a time about the topics and texts under discussion).

C152DB388ED04948894729807DD1B5F1.description: Consult reference materials as needed to check and correct spellings.

D0AC3F8277A7428AB8BF5D2353891E3F.description: Identify and use learned spelling patterns when writing words (e.g., long and short vowels, vowel/consonant digraphs, trigraphs, consonant clusters/blends, vowel r, and base/affixes).

8344F785504A4863A2BDBDB1ABAAC54C.description: Use apostrophes to form contractions and frequently occurring possessives.

073BE368889146D3A6BD0AAAC46CBC58.description: Use ending punctuation marks as well as commas in greetings and closings of letters.

B202E802F11A4C81939C84B971BC9CD0.description: Use capitals at the beginning of every sentence and capitalize proper nouns (e.g., holidays, product names, and geographic names).Â

6EF4D150D0C54D13815E15498739A2C4.description: Form and use simple verb tenses (e.g., I walked; I walk; I will walk).

6F12A3D527634A1482B0AEEBC921AE5E.description: Produce and expand simple and compound sentences.

60BEEB8D3A7C4934AFF661EE3BCC3E8A.description: Identify adjectives and adverbs, and choose between them depending on what is being modified.

5F37B3D6EE0D4C24840CB8C0CE3B2CC8.description: Form and use the past tense of frequently occurring irregular verbs.

3D3479FC8D4940E8A5D38F7A7D29DD9B.description: Form and use frequently occurring irregular plural nouns.Â

3602A5F3ABFC425D83289D566B2EEB9B.description: Include details to describe actions, thoughts, and feelings in narrative pieces.

A800D40591444064A3819D07BABDF149.description: Write to teach your reader by including facts, definitions, details, steps, or tips in informative/explanatory pieces.

FA36BCE7B7BC41D7935A664B1A9B57CC.description: Supply reasons to support your opinion and write a few sentences about each reason.

332C2EEFF77143BDA6A6F22C3AB848A2.description: Â Write well-elaborated narrative pieces; recount an event or short sequence of events, use temporal words to signal event order, and provide a sense of closure.

CDFF929AC1144814888A4F8A565DBE3B.description: Write informative/explanatory pieces; introduce a topic, separate different information into parts and provide a concluding statement or section.

A5FB615DC9D94D9BADD2C0EF7AB96011.description: Write opinion pieces; introduce the topic, supply reasons that support the opinion, use linking words (e.g., because, and, also) to connect opinion and reasons, and provide a concluding statement or section.

FCD58E739D074881AAB3B2A5D0983AE1.description: Compare and contrast the most important points presented by two texts on the same topic.

4AE358505BA1412FB8D2AC839E131960.description: Describe how reasons support specific points the author makes in a text.

B846F364225147B88160F93407A549D8.description: Explain how specific images (e.g., a diagram showing how a machine works) contribute to and clarify a text.

745574605D95485984B9F3E7D4A1D26B.description: Identify the main purpose of a text including what the author wants to answer, explain, or describe.

E3FC8B120BD94B97B335D3DB83836C13.description: Locate key facts or information in a text efficiently by using various text features (e.g., captions, bold print, subheadings, glossaries, indexes, electronic menus, and icons).

06CC5F76953F412D85C08BF7F35531AE.description: Explain the connection between a series of historical events, scientific ideas or concepts, or steps in technical procedures in a text.

71A8EF52500A4ED89ECF0F388BFC5BD7.description: Identify the main topic of a multiparagraph text as well as the focus of specific paragraphs within the text.

F6C420BEBC214DBD90AE095E03853E2C.description: Ask and answer such questions as who, what, when, where, why, and how to demonstrate understanding of key details in a text.

D95334C219834B13A66BCF9724803D3F.description: Compare and contrast two or more versions of the same story (e.g., Cinderella stories) by different authors or from different cultures.Â

AE206AB5823E47C0B9FA2E3CFCE58A43.description: Use information gained from the illustrations and words in a print or digital text to demonstrate understanding of its characters, setting, or plot.Â

A8A75991615240D0B6C77A85ADBEB386.description: Acknowledge differences in the points of view of characters, including speaking in a different voice for each character when reading dialogue aloud.

010CB43CB6FF4C51B14FC2D08858CD0B.description: Describe the overall structure of a story, including how the beginning introduces the story and the ending concludes the action.

19387160D3E1422795818EA5F6C9713D.description: Describe how characters in a story respond to major events and challenges.

ACB0A3E827C04032BAF4AB4AD901081C.description: Determine the central message, lesson, or moral of stories from diverse cultures

E2CD4F155D054D06BC04BD5FB72346C8.description: Recount stories, including fables and folktales from diverse cultures.

EE030E4848154D64A1CFBCAE539B8ED3.description: Ask and answer such questions as who, what, when, where, why, and how to demonstrate understanding of key details in a text.Â

012EEFEB814244B4A3B9AC77534109A3.description: Â Divide circles, rectangles, and squares into two, three, or four equal shares using halves, thirds, half of, a third of, etc. and describe the whole as two halves, three thirds, and four fourths.

8E68236B802E47C08B6198CB8906C4BB.description: Divide a rectangle into rows and columns of the same size squares and count to find the total number of squares.

F4B548B7BED14B418A4775592CBC982C.description: Draw previously mastered two-dimensional shapes given a specific number of line segments/sides and angles (see appendix).

3D1C5CD7270542EC9510E473BC79400B.description: Explain the difference between two given shapes (see appendix) using words (angles and faces) to describe their attributes.

C84A26DF13A5476D92B85B62EBAB83CA.description: Identify and draw up to four lines of symmetry on previously mastered shapes.

4B75AF660D954A97ADA178B6D8859141.description: Identify the base and the number of faces, edges, and vertices on previously introduced shapes and three-dimensional shapes (see appendix).

12A2F3ADB6114D6184ED5C180C0CFCD2.description: Identify, draw, and name: points, lines, and line segments.

4EF721689EA14684BA83E8DF0C126584.description: Identify the number of angles and line segments/sides in previously identified two-dimensional shapes.

C1F4FC8DB1C54A7CBE05BED480C0D8B9.description: Classify previously mastered shapes (see appendix) as quadrilaterals and/or polygons.

F7EEE094217246AF8737F342AAB7868D.description: Solve simple put-together, take-apart, and compare problems using information presented in picture graphs and bar graphs.

4C04D50BCB9644BD900044B68AC13E72.description: Create a picture graph, a bar graph, and a line plot, given a constructed template, with a single-unit scale to represent a collected data set with up to four categories.

9B7CD599F8F54481936D843BCD560CE5.description: Collect data including time, temperature, and measurement by tallying the results.

22C502BF1A424FC082770A7AF1AE3E02.description: Use a thermometer in Fahrenheit and Celsius to solve temperature problems up to 100 degrees.

A0CAEF20D9DA4B4FA76B700C4624DB95.description: Solve simple real world problems using time.  For example, What time do you wake up? 8:00 a.m.

D23E7117F7DE449587AFF9A2775C8604.description: Tell and write time from analog and digital clocks to the nearest five minutes, using a.m. and p.m.

E4AE15F1435446EB9CC7E052374F3B88.description: Solve real world addition and subtraction problems using manipulatives or calculators, involving dollar bills, quarters, dimes, nickels, and pennies, using $ or Â¢ (symbols) up to $5.00.

2DAB4E731D0D4013BE253E17B2F385CF.description: Calculate accurately the change needed up to $1.00.

D345A00C1A5A4C7199952C3CAD9CC0D6.description: Identify coin equivalencies using pennies, nickels, dimes, and quarters and make coin exchanges.

07C8343A7FA54EA3B802485C188205DF.description: Identify the value of a given combination of coins and compare sets of money using  < , > ,  = up to $5.00.

AD61C1523DC64D8F863A16DB7533DDB5.description: Compute the value of coins and bills in combinations to $5.00.

F4F45A5605324D1DB46CA76022BB37C8.description: Identify and write the value of pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters, $1.00 bills, and $5.00 bills using dollar-and-cent notation. For example, a nickel=$0.05

B21ADB583AAE465FA93F0A500DA6CA26.description: Solve addition and subtraction real word problems within 100 involving lengths that are given in same units using number lines, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.

8AC3ABAA512E481A92012D6354A6CB9A.description: Solve perimeter problems by measuring all the whole number side lengths of a polygon.

E8AED6C7C13F45A5B32FDB164DCA1DA1.description: Â Define perimeter as the distance around the outside of a polygon.

2FBF01156BFC405AA51BB421D9879F90.description: Measure in standard units (inches, feet, centimeters, meters) to  determine how much longer one object is than another.Â

3A39467E27D54C4EAE30915C590CE49C.description: Estimate lengths using units of inches, feet, centimeters and meters.

6ECC7D1577DA447EAF13BFD532CB9CC4.description: Compare the length of an object measured twice, using different length units(for example feet and inches) and explain how the two measurements relate to the size of the units chosen.

9DA00FB736D148049627C28ECD2A1541.description: Measure a line segment to the nearest half inch.

6F5A788F08BC4B40B2321BFD00C1B05F.description: Select appropriate tool used for measuring such as a ruler, yardstick, meter stick, and tape-measure.

C9F6AC002EFA4F308DDE6333B2769964.description: Estimate and solve real world problems using addition and subtraction strategies and justify the solution by explaining the strategy used.Â

ED57CDA8622D470DA5BBD72D28B9FBC9.description: Add and subtract two three-digit numbers with regrouping using concrete models and explain the strategy in writing.

991255E6B753496C863677D997BC3734.description: Subtract numbers within 100 using strategies based on place value properties of operations.Â

35B0FAF90A4E4366BD8FAC78C92CA8F2.description: Add up to four two-digit numbers using strategies based on place value properties of operations.Â

2172E25E0E1341B9B31BFEA203967233.description: Round a single number to the nearest 10âs or 100âs place and estimate solutions to addition and subtraction problems.Â

630840B625794C36A82631D824EC3E00.description: Justify and model why addition and subtraction strategies work using place value and the properties of operations with problems of 2 or 3 digits.Â

63C1645572C0415B8F8E04C81E00AC6C.description: Mentally add and subtract 10s or 100s to any number 100-1,000.Â

386691287FE64FEFA0A85542A73A34AC.description: Read and write 2, 3, 4-digit numbers using standard form and number names.Â

F391182DF3E145FC9AC83DD1AF2E61E3.description: Make exchanges among place values using manipulatives. For example, 100 is 10 tens.Â

E2D060CB44B34950BA16D0A56930D56F.description: Identify the value of each digit in a 2, 3, or 4-digit number and write the number in expanded form. For example, 706 equals 7 hundreds, 0 tens, 6ones.

A21A291518DA43CDBD38EE62BD879283.description: Identify place value in 2, 3, 4-digit numbers.  For example, in the number 4,267 the 2 is in the hundreds place.Â

143036C55E7B424FA1371B9F4E391F1A.description: Add and subtract within 100 without regrouping using strategies including repeated addition, skip counting, fact retrieval (identifying even and odd numbers).

3D9D7C9BB66F40C5A0EDB396CE4E9D76.description: Count within 1,000; skip-count by 5s, 10s, 100s and identify and explain the pattern.

0B9FA87F424243FEB13EE42966D8E302.description: Identify equivalent names for numbers up to 100. For example, 8 can equal 8 tally marks, 4 +4, 8 pennies, etc.

D5E4A9370F6047D08E8C67BDB0078225.description: Number and Operations in Base Ten

2C2054287ECE4FAB8A6FF0D4169763D5.description: Use mental arithmetic strategies to add and subtract problems within 20.

BC0659701313448CA3A536E94DC5E1AC.description: Identify whether a number is odd or even and use objects, pictures, or equations to explain whether a number up to 100 has an odd or even number of members.

8EBD13E0193743F58F506DF9E388B98E.description: Add to find the total number of objects arranged in rectangular arrays with up to five rows and up to five columns; write an equation to express as a sum of equal addends.

FABEFFCFB3BF4E69B96137BBE1F8F6DA.description: Add three one-digit numbers with sums to 27.Â

424E8B7123074FDD84C4EAA9BD793644.description: List one and two digit fact families. For example, 3+4=7, 30 +40=70Â

75BADB6C42DF426FBB29FFCFE6652E89.description: Create and solve one and two-step addition and subtraction real world problems within 100 by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown.
